subject: Re: [junit] boilerplate for testEquals, testCompareTo, testHashCode  wanted
msgSnippet: Hi, Thanks for the pointer - however,for this question I think the actual implementation of, say, equals() is less of an issue here. What I was thinking that
messageBody:
Hi,
Thanks for the pointer - however,for this question I
think the actual implementation of, say, equals() is
less of an issue here. What I was thinking that for a
given representation you'll be needing to 'prove' that
you are meeting the contractual obligations - whether
actual implementation is efficient or elegant or
whatever is a side issue.

You're right in that you can't assume it'll work for
all real world input just because it works for an
example. This increases the desire for boilerplate
code, as you'll have to work up multiple tests using
normal test design strategies to try and ensure that
it's 'probably' working as intended - i.e. testing
objects with state at boundary values, nonsensical
values etc etc

Chris
--- NOUSHI Reda <noushi@...> wrote: > Hi,
> I have no boiler plate, but a suggestion, if it
> could be of any
> enlightenment...
> There's this article on DrDobb's showing how to
> implement a better
> equals method. It's this month's edition.
> I have a reamrk though: how can you assume, and that
> relates to tests in
> general, that if it works for an example, it'll work
> for all other
> cases?
>
> Regards,
> Reda
